citation.article-title: Two new genera of nocardioform actinomycetes; Amycolata gen. nov. and Amycolatopsis gen. nov.

p.s: Amycolatopsis (A.my.co.la.top'sis. M.L. fem. n. Amycolata genus belonging to the order Actinomycetales; Gr. n. opsis appearance; M.L. fem. n. Amycolatopsis that which appears similar to Amycolata)
Actinomycetes forming branching vegetative hyphae with a diameter of 0.5 to 2.0 Î¼m, which tend to break down into squarish subunits.
Aerial mycelium may or may not be present.
Aerial hyphae, when formed, may be sterile or break down into chains of squarish to oval fragments or sporelike structures.
No endospores, sheaths, synnemata, sporangia, or sclerotia are present.
Not susceptible to phages specific for the Nocardia-Rhodococcus complex, Saccharomonospora, and Faenia.

Type IV cell wall composition (meso-diaminopimelic acid, glutamic acid, alanine, muramic acid, glucosamine, galactose, and arabinose); type A whole-cell sugar pattern (galactose and arabinose present; no madurose, fucose or xylose; rhamnose variably present).

Type PII phospholipid pattern (phosphatidylethanolamine present with or without phosphatidylmethylethanolamine) in addition to (variably) phosphatidylinositol mannosides, phosphatidylinositol, and diphosphatidylglycerol.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the DNA ranges from 66 to 69 mol%.
The type species is Amycolatopsis orientalis.
